1. A 9-year-old male presents to the pediatric genetics clinic with progressive vision loss and night blindness over the past two years. His parents report he has developmental delays and difficulty with coordination, often tripping while walking. On examination, he has central obesity, polydactyly on both hands, and mild intellectual disability. Fundoscopic exam reveals pigmentary retinopathy consistent with retinitis pigmentosa. Family history is notable for consanguineous parents and a cousin with similar symptoms. Renal ultrasound shows mild structural abnormalities without significant dysfunction. Blood tests demonstrate no immediate metabolic derangement, but his lipid profile is abnormal. Genetic testing confirms a pathogenic mutation in the BBS15 gene, supporting the diagnosis of Bardet-Biedl Syndrome type 15.
